issues.description: The UML in the problem statement names the class 'Course' (lines 63–74) while the textual description, tasks, and both the template and solution repositories consistently refer to a 'Lecture' class. This inconsistent class name in the UML can confuse students when they cross-check the diagram with the instructions and the provided template (which contains a Lecture class), although it does not make implementation impossible.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the UML in the problem statement to use the class name 'Lecture' (instead of 'Course') so it matches the text and the provided template and solution. Example: change 'class Course {' to 'class Lecture {'. This keeps the pedagogical intent while removing the naming inconsistency that may confuse students.

issues.description: The problem text and code refer to the class students should implement as 'Lecture' (text, template and solution), but the UML diagram embedded in the problem statement declares the class as 'Course'. This inconsistent class name within the problem statement can confuse students when mapping the UML to the required implementation (they may look for or expect a 'Course' class instead of the provided 'Lecture' class).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the class name consistent across the problem statement and code. Rename the UML class from 'Course' to 'Lecture' so it matches the textual description and the provided template/solution (or, if 'Course' is intended, update the problem text and template/solution to use 'Course'). Prefer changing the UML to 'Lecture' to preserve the current template and solution.
